TypeSignature.Value: .class public auto ansi abstract sealed beforefieldinit WhiteningExtensions extends System.Object

Docs.summary: Extensions for statically typed Whitening estimator.

MemberSignature.Value: public static Microsoft.ML.StaticPipe.Vector<float> PcaWhitening (this Microsoft.ML.StaticPipe.Vector<float> input, float eps = 1E-05, int maxRows = 100000, bool saveInverse = false, int pcaNum = 0);

.method public static hidebysig class Microsoft.ML.StaticPipe.Vector`1<float32> PcaWhitening(class Microsoft.ML.StaticPipe.Vector`1<float32> input, float32 eps, int32 maxRows, bool saveInverse, int32 pcaNum) cil managed

<Extension()> Public Function PcaWhitening (input As Vector(Of Single), Optional eps As Single = 1E-05, Optional maxRows As Integer = 100000, Optional saveInverse As Boolean = false, Optional pcaNum As Integer = 0) As Vector(Of Single)
static member PcaWhitening : Microsoft.ML.StaticPipe.Vector<single> * single * int * bool * int -> Microsoft.ML.StaticPipe.Vector<single>

Docs.summary: Implements PCA (Principal Component Analysis) and ZCA (Zero phase Component Analysis) whitening. The whitening process consists of 2 steps: 1. Decorrelation of the input data. Input data is assumed to have zero mean. 2. Rescale decorrelated features to have unit variance. That is, PCA whitening is essentially just a PCA + rescale. ZCA whitening tries to make resulting data to look more like input data by rotating it back to the original input space. More information: http://ufldl.stanford.edu/wiki/index.php/Whitening

Docs.summary: Implements PCA (Principal Component Analysis) and ZCA (Zero phase Component Analysis) whitening. The whitening process consists of 2 steps: 1. Decorrelation of the input data. Input data is assumed to have zero mean. 2. Rescale decorrelated features to have unit variance. That is, PCA whitening is essentially just a PCA + rescale. ZCA whitening tries to make resulting data to look more like input data by rotating it back to the original input space. More information: http://ufldl.stanford.edu/wiki/index.php/Whitening
